deliberation: The verse is a historical heading describing Jeremiah’s letter and its addressees. No comparisons, idioms, personifications, or other non‑literal uses beyond normal prose. All terms (elders, priests, prophets, exile, Jerusalem, Babylon) are straightforward and literal.

This verse simply lists groups of people who went into exile (king, queen mother, eunuchs, officials, artisans, smiths). No metaphor, simile, idiom, or personification is used; the language is descriptive and literal.
The narrative explains the transmission of the letter. The only potentially figurative element is the idiom בְּיַד ("by the hand of"), which uses a body part metonymically for agency/mediation.

instances.english_text: [The letter was sent] through Elasah son of Shaphan and Gemariah son of Hilkiah
ground: agency and instrumentality in carrying something
instances.explanation: The phrase "by the hand of" uses "hand" metonymically as an idiom for the agency of the messengers through whom the letter is delivered.

deliberation: The verse is a divine speech introduction. The epithet "YHWH of Hosts" (יְהוָה צְבָאוֹת) is a fixed, metaphorically loaded title that pictures God as commander over vast 'hosts' (armies/celestial or earthly), functioning metonymically to highlight His power.

instances.english_text: GOD of Hosts
target: YHWH as sovereign over all powers
ground: authority to command, martial power, vast resources
instances.explanation: The title "YHWH of Hosts" metaphorically and metonymically presents God as the commander of vast armies (heavenly or earthly), emphasizing His supreme power.

deliberation: On the surface, the commands to build houses, dwell, plant gardens, and eat their fruit are literal. Collectively, however, they function synecdochically as a compact picture of settled, long‑term life in exile, representing the broader idea of establishing stable existence there.

instances.hebrew_text: בְּנ֥וּ בָתִּ֖ים וְשֵׁ֑בוּ וְנִטְע֣וּ גַנּ֔וֹת וְאִכְל֖וּ אֶת־פִּרְיָֽן
instances.english_text: Build houses and live in them, plant gardens and eat their fruit.
target: the exiles’ entire settled life in Babylon
ground: permanence, rootedness, productivity in one place
posture: divine encouragement to accept long exile
instances.explanation: The concrete acts of building houses and planting gardens function as a synecdoche for fully settling and establishing long‑term life in Babylon, rather than expecting a quick return.

deliberation: Commands about taking wives, having children, and multiplying are literal instructions, echoing creation language but without a clear, discrete metaphor, idiom, or personification beyond that. The emphasis is on actual procreation, not a figurative increase.

The central phrase is "seek the welfare of the city" and "in its welfare you will have welfare." Here "city" functions metonymically for its inhabitants/structures, and "welfare/shalom" is a holistic concept but used straightforwardly. The main figurative device is the city-as-people metonymy.

instances.hebrew_text: שְׁלוֹם הָעִיר אֲשֶׁר הִגְלֵיתִי אֶתְכֶם שָׁמָּה ... כִּי בִשְׁלוֹמָהּ יִהְיֶה לָכֶם שָׁלוֹם
instances.english_text: the welfare of the city to which I have exiled you ... for in its prosperity you shall prosper.
target: the wellbeing of Babylon’s inhabitants and systems
social/political condition of the host society
ground: a city stands for the community that lives and functions within it
posture: divine directive reorienting the exiles' attitude to Babylon
instances.explanation: The term "city" is used metonymically to refer not to the walls and buildings but to the entire community and its welfare, on which the exiles’ own shalom depends.

deliberation: The verse warns against deception by prophets, diviners, and self‑generated dreams. The expressions are straightforward; "dreams they dream" is not a special idiom beyond the literal act of dreaming. No clear metaphor, simile, or idiom stands out.
The statement about false prophecy is direct. 'Prophesy falsely in My name' is literal description of their activity. No figurative comparisons, idioms, or personifications appear.

The verse speaks of seventy years and returning to the place; these are temporal and spatial statements. The notable figurative element is the verb פָּקַד ("I will visit/take note of you"), which in this covenant context is an idiom for decisive divine intervention, not physical visiting.

instances.english_text: I will take note of you / I will visit you
target: YHWH’s decisive redemptive action for the exiles
ground: a personal visit stands for purposeful engagement and action toward someone
instances.explanation: The verb פקד in this context is an idiom using "visiting" metonymically for God’s concrete intervention on their behalf, not a literal physical visit.

deliberation: This verse attributes "thoughts/plans" to God and speaks of a "future and hope." These are standard anthropomorphic and abstract terms within biblical theology, but no sharply delimited metaphor, simile, or idiom is formed beyond conventional God‑as‑planner language.

Prayer language ('call,' 'come,' 'pray,' 'I will listen') is standard and not used in a strikingly figurative way here. It describes actual petition and divine response without a distinct metaphor or idiom that stands out.

Two conceptual metaphors are present: (1) seeking and finding God, and (2) "with all your heart" as an idiom. The clearest discrete figurative expression is 'with all your heart,' where 'heart' stands metonymically for the inner self/whole person, functioning as an idiom for total commitment.

instances.english_text: wholeheartedly / with all your heart
target: the exiles’ entire inner commitment and will
ground: the heart as the perceived center of thought, will, and emotion stands for the whole inner person
instances.explanation: The phrase "with all your heart" is an idiomatic metaphor where the heart stands metonymically for the entire inner person, expressing total, undivided seeking of God.

deliberation: The verse describes gathering from nations and returning—primarily literal restoration imagery. The phrase "restore your fortunes" / "turn your captivity" (וְשַׁבְתִּי אֶת־שְׁבוּתְכֶם/שביתכם) is a well-known Hebrew idiom for reversing a people’s condition, not literally handing back physical goods or prisoners.

instances.english_text: I will restore your fortunes / I will restore your captivity
target: the exiles’ overall changed situation for the better
ground: reversing captivity symbolizes a complete change from misfortune to wellbeing
instances.explanation: The idiom "restore your fortunes" (literally, "turn your captivity") uses captivity/fortune metonymically for the people’s overall condition, promising a total reversal of their state.

deliberation: The people claim that YHWH has "raised up" prophets for them. The verb הֵקִים ("raise up") used with "prophets" is an idiom/metaphor for appointing or bringing into office, not literal physical lifting.

instances.english_text: GOD has raised up prophets for us
ground: to cause someone to stand up evokes bringing them into prominence or function
instances.explanation: The phrase "raise up prophets" metaphorically and idiomatically describes God’s appointing and commissioning of prophets, using physical "raising" as an image for installing into office.

deliberation: The verse addresses the king "who sits on the throne of David" and the people in the city. The key figurative element is "throne of David" as a metonym/metaphor for the Davidic kingship and dynasty, not just the physical chair.

instances.english_text: the king who sits on the throne of David
target: the current Davidic kingship and royal authority
ground: a throne symbolizes and stands for rule, authority, and dynastic continuity
instances.explanation: The "throne of David" uses the physical royal seat as a metonymic and metaphorical expression for the Davidic kingship and its authority.

deliberation: Two figurative elements stand out: (1) the triad "sword, famine, and pestilence" as a stock metonymic formula for comprehensive covenant judgment; (2) the explicit simile likening the people to loathsome figs that cannot be eaten.

instances.english_text: sword, famine, and pestilence
target: YHWH’s comprehensive judgment on the remaining population
ground: these are emblematic tools by which a people is destroyed or disciplined
instances.explanation: The triad "sword, famine, pestilence" is a stereotyped formula functioning metonymically for thoroughgoing covenant judgment upon a nation.

instances.hebrew_text: וְנָתַתִּ֣י אוֹתָ֗ם כַּתְּאֵנִים֙ הַשֹּׁ֣עָרִ֔ים אֲשֶׁ֥ר לֹא־תֵאָכַ֖לְנָה מֵרֹֽעַ
instances.english_text: and I will treat them as loathsome figs, so bad that they cannot be eaten.
ground: shared quality of being unfit for consumption/acceptance
instances.explanation: The people are explicitly compared to repulsive figs that cannot be eaten, a simile (and hyperbolic image) stressing their utter unacceptability and impending rejection.

deliberation: Again the triad "sword, famine, pestilence" appears as covenant-judgment metonymy. Additionally, the statement that God will "make them a horror, an execration, a desolation, a hissing, and a reproach" metaphorically turns the people into embodiments of these responses/conditions, a hyperbolic image of extreme disgrace.

instances.english_text: with the sword, with famine, and with pestilence
ground: these are representative instruments through which destruction is experienced
instances.explanation: As in v.17, the triad functions as a stereotyped metonymic expression for full-spectrum covenant judgment.

instances.hebrew_text: וּנְתַתִּ֨ים ... לְזַעֲוָ֜ה ... לְאָלָ֤ה וּלְשַׁמָּה֙ וְלִשְׁרֵקָ֣ה וּלְחֶרְפָּ֔ה
instances.english_text: and I will make them a horror ... an execration and an object of horror and hissing and scorn
target: the reputation and symbolic status of the judged people
their role as a warning example
ground: they will so embody calamity that they become a living symbol provoking horror and mockery
instances.explanation: The people are metaphorically made into "a horror, an execration, a desolation, a hissing, and a reproach"—a hyperbolic image of them as walking symbols of curse and disgrace among the nations.

deliberation: The key figurative phrase is the idiom "rising early and sending" (הַשְׁכֵּם וְשָׁלֹחַ) used of God sending prophets. It anthropomorphically pictures God as persistently getting up early to send messengers, a vivid idiom for repeated, diligent initiative.

instances.hebrew_text: אֲשֶׁר֩ שָׁלַ֨חְתִּי אֲלֵיהֶ֜ם אֶת־עֲבָדַ֤י הַנְּבִאִים֙ הַשְׁכֵּ֣ם וְשָׁלֹ֔חַ
instances.english_text: when I persistently sent to them My servants, the prophets (literally, "rising early and sending")
ground: getting up early to send someone suggests earnestness, priority, and repetition
instances.explanation: The idiom "rising early and sending" personifies God as a diligent human who repeatedly gets up early to send messengers, a metaphorical way of stressing His persistent warnings through the prophets.

deliberation: This is an exhortation formula: 'hear the word of YHWH.' The phrase is standard prophetic diction; 'word' stands for message, but this is minimal, conventional metonymy. No stronger, distinctive figurative expression stands out.

The verse introduces judgment on two false prophets. The phrase "I am giving them into the hand of Nebuchadrezzar" (נֹתֵן אֹתָם בְּיַד) is a common idiom/metonymy where "hand" stands for power or control.

instances.english_text: I am going to deliver them into the hands of King Nebuchadrezzar of Babylon
target: their being subjected to Nebuchadrezzar’s power
vehicle: controlling hand as seat of power
ground: the hand is used for grasping and controlling, so it stands for power over someone
instances.explanation: The idiom "give into the hand" uses "hand" metonymically for a person’s power and control, signifying that the false prophets will be fully subject to Nebuchadrezzar.

deliberation: Their fate becomes a template for a curse formula. The key figurative element is "a curse shall be taken from them" (וְלֻקַּח מֵהֶם קְלָלָה), where their names/events are metonymically turned into a proverbial curse expression.

instances.english_text: And the whole community of Judah in Babylonia shall use a curse derived from their fate
target: the use of their fate as a curse formula
ground: their story becomes shorthand for an extreme, dreaded fate
instances.explanation: The phrase pictures the community "taking" a curse from them—using their fate metonymically as the content of later curse formulas ("May God make you like Zedekiah and Ahab").

deliberation: Their sins (adultery, false prophecy) are described literally. God's self‑description "I am the one who knows and bears witness" is straightforward; it attributes knowing and witnessing to God but not in a distinctive figurative expression beyond standard theology.
This is a simple narrative transition introducing Shemaiah the Nehelamite. No metaphor, idiom, or personification appears; 'you shall say' is literal instruction.

The verse recounts Shemaiah sending letters 'in your own name' and addresses Zephaniah and the priests. The divine title recurs, but no new distinctive figurative constructions appear beyond formulaic language.

Shemaiah describes those who "prophesy" as "every maniac" (כׇּל־אִישׁ מְשֻׁגָּע וּמִתְנַבֵּא), equating prophetic behavior with madness—a hostile metaphor, arguably hyperbolic, casting genuine prophets as lunatics.

instances.english_text: over every maniac who wants to play the prophet
ground: from Shemaiah’s viewpoint, prophetic behavior seems irrational or frenzied
instances.explanation: Shemaiah metaphorically labels those prophesying as "maniacs," a hyperbolic comparison that equates prophetic speech with insanity to discredit Jeremiah and others.

deliberation: Shemaiah asks why Zephaniah has not rebuked Jeremiah. 'Jeremiah the Anathothite' and 'who prophesies to you' are literal descriptions; no figurative language is present beyond the polemical context already captured in v.26.

Shemaiah reports Jeremiah’s message: 'It will be a long time. Build houses and live in them, plant gardens and eat their fruit.' As in v.5, these concrete activities function synecdochically for settling in for the long haul in Babylon.

instances.hebrew_text: בְּנ֤וּ בָתִּים֙ וְשֵׁ֔בוּ וְנִטְע֣וּ גַנּ֔וֹת וְאִכְל֖וּ אֶת־פְּרִיהֶֽן
instances.english_text: Build houses and live in them, plant gardens and enjoy their fruit.
target: the exiles’ long-term, settled existence in Babylon
vehicle: building houses, planting and eating from gardens
ground: these acts are emblematic of permanent settlement and normal life
instances.explanation: Here, as in v.5, house‑building and gardening serve as a synecdoche for fully settling into Babylonian life for a long period, rather than expecting an imminent return.

deliberation: Zephaniah reads the letter "in the hearing" (literally "in the ears") of Jeremiah. This is a common Hebrew way of saying someone heard, and in this narrative setting it reflects actual auditory reception, not a marked figure beyond light body‑part metonymy. No distinct figurative expression stands out.

The formula "the word of YHWH came to Jeremiah" personifies the divine word as an active agent that 'comes' to the prophet. It is a standard prophetic idiom combining metonymy (word for message) and personification.

instances.english_text: the word of GOD came to Jeremiah
target: the reception of a prophetic revelation by Jeremiah
ground: a message is depicted as an active emissary arriving to someone
instances.explanation: The expression personifies the divine "word" as if it were an agent that can come to Jeremiah, an idiomatic way of describing prophetic revelation.

deliberation: The key figurative phrase is "made you trust in a lie" (וַיַּבְטַח אֶתְכֶם עַל־שָׁקֶר). Trust is pictured as resting 'on' something, here 'a lie,' creating a spatial metaphor of relying on a faulty foundation.

instances.english_text: and made you false promises / made you trust in a lie
target: the people’s misplaced confidence in Shemaiah’s message
act of relying on false assurances
vehicle: trusting "on" a lie as on a support
standing or resting on something unstable
ground: confidence is conceptualized as being supported by or resting upon something; a lie is an unreliable foundation
instances.explanation: The phrase uses a spatial metaphor, picturing trust as resting upon a foundation; in this case, the 'foundation' is a lie, highlighting the precariousness of their confidence.

deliberation: God declares that Shemaiah will not have a descendant "dwelling" among the people and that he will not "see the good" which God does. The latter phrase "see the good" (לֹא־יִרְאֶה בַטּוֹב) uses seeing metaphorically for experiencing/participating in blessing.

instances.english_text: and [he] shall not see the good things I am going to do for My people
target: Shemaiah’s exclusion from experiencing future blessing
ground: to see something is to encounter or experience it firsthand
posture: denial of share in promised good
instances.explanation: The idiom "not see the good" uses sight as a metaphor for personal experience, meaning Shemaiah will not personally partake in the blessings God will bring to His people.
